data.text: He that is merciful will lend unto his neighbour;
Lend to thy neighbour in time of his need,
Keep thy word, and deal faithfully with him,
Many, when a thing was lent them, reckoned it to be found,
Till he hath received, he will kiss a man’s hand;
If he prevail, he shall hardly receive the half,
Many therefore have refused to lend for other men’s ill dealing,
Yet have thou patience with a man in poor estate,
Help the poor for the commandment’s sake,
Lose thy money for thy brother and thy friend,
Lay up thy treasure according to the commandments of the most High,
Shut up alms in thy storehouses:
It shall fight for thee against thine enemies
An honest man is surety for his neighbour:
Forget not the friendship of thy surety,
A sinner will overthrow the good estate of his surety:
And he that is of an unthankful mind will leave him in danger that delivered him.
Suretiship hath undone many of good estate,
A wicked man transgressing the commandments of the Lord shall fall into suretiship:
Help thy neighbour according to thy power,
The chief thing for life is water, and bread,
Better is the life of a poor man in a mean cottage,
Be it little or much, hold thee contented,
For it is a miserable life to go from house to house:
Thou shalt entertain, and feast, and have no thanks:
Come, thou stranger, and furnish a table,
Give place, thou stranger, to an honourable man;
These things are grievous to a man of understanding;
